Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2013 07:45AM beacon800 wrote: Gosh, I am sorry your breasts are such a difficult thing.  I do understand.  I had very cystic breasts which scared me as they were always lumpy and I always felt things.  I guess from age 42 onward, they always felt bad.  They hurt too, around my period.  My mom had breast cancer and died from it.  I hated the mammos/ and ultrasounds and mine always took a long time. However I never thought of preventative surgery until I had an actual diagnosis of high grade LCIS at age 48.  This is not considered cancer and my doctors were not sure I was right to request bilateral mastectomy.  But I wanted it and we did it.  I am very, very happy this way. In your shoes I don't think I would do it yet.  I would wait and see if anything at all abnormal comes of it.  Maybe at the first sign of trouble you can take action?  Frankly, you may never get cancer.  You may just have lumpy tedious breasts until you are post menopausal, which means, yes you have some years ahead of you for testing, etc. Most mastectomy patients do ok.  Some have significant trouble with pain, range of motion, numbness, lymphedema.  However, the majority seem to do ok.  It's a big deal of a surgery though.  Things can go wrong and each woman is different.  I would hold off, if it were me, til I got some warning of trouble.  Are your breasts considered "dense"?  Can you stand to afford MRI (cause your insurance probably won't pay) to keep a high level of surveillance?  Have you talked about the idea of taking Tamoxifen even though you don't have a cancer diagnosis?  (you can't take it if pregnant though, I think)

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 08:28PM - edited Feb 17, 2012 08:29PM by beacon800 SandiK I am so sorry they got a result of breast cancer.  (((hugs))).  You'll want to get a copy of the pathology report and the report detailing the status of the hormonal receptors (estrogen, progesterone and HER2)  Those things tell alot about the type of cancer that you have and how you can tackle it. Make sure you go to a breast oncology surgeon, rather than a general surgeon, if at all possible for your surgery.  Breast oncology surgeons do only breast cancer surgery and they have huge expertise.  Sadly they are also extremely busy which tells a lot.  Everyone here will help you and you will get through.  Sorry you are facing this, but you are not alone, there is an army of people to help you.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 09:47PM beacon800 wrote: SandiK, so sorry to hear of the complexities on your very first mammogram.  Blah, that is something and all of us here know exactly how stressful this is.  Biopsy will reveal all, so you'll just have to wait, there is not much else you can do. Your mammo is rating a BIRADS 0.  That means "incomplete".  It means they don't have enuf information on that mammo to make a full statement about the findings.  The ultrasound is rating BIRADS 4, meaning, suspicious, biopsy indicated.  That is not the worst it can be.  The worst is BIRADS 5, where they are just almost totally sure it is cancer.  For what it's worth, I had numerous films giving BIRADS 4 and the subsequent biopsies never found cancer.  So BIRADS 4 is not meaning you have cancer. It's just a rough time for you right now and I am sure others will give more info.  Meanwhile, do anything you can to reduce your stress and DO NOT google all this stuff or you will go insane.  No joke!! (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2012 02:51AM beacon800 wrote: Mid third means what they see is in the middle of your breast from front to back.  The front third is near the skin, the back third is near the chest wall.  Yours is between. Clustered microcalcifications are tiny bits of calcuim deposits.  It is common for women to have calcium deposits in the breasts and it does not mean cancer.  However sometimes the arrangement and type of calcium deposits is happening due to cancer.  Overall, you would rather see isolated calcium deposits rather than clustered or linear formations.  More likely benign when isolated. Spiculatated means there are branching formations around a mass.  Kind of like rays from a star.  Not sure if they see a mass, as it did not say so.  Perhaps the arrangement of the calcifications is leading them to use this term.  Spiculated masses are worrisome as cancer is often in that shape.  It still does not mean you have cancer.  They will biopsy this for you and find out.  Hope all is benign!

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 07:26PM beacon800 wrote: Me!  I'm happy.  I had bilaterals for LCIS.  It went very well.  I use many different types of forms depending on my mood and outfit.  When you are post surgery there is a healing period when you might not want to wear any forms, or only little cotton fluff ones.  This will be 6-8 weeks.  Then you can start to do what pleases you.  I use the microbead forms a lot.  These are from TLC on line catalog.  Cheap and utterly weightless.  I use them in regular bras and I just sew a bit of soft fabric over the inside cup to make a holder for the micro bead form.  By far the most comfortable bra I have ever used, including pre surgery.  For sports I use the foam forms, also from TLC.  They are very lightweight but hold their shape stronger than the microbead forms.  I use these in a nylon Hanes bra that does not mind getting sweaty. If I want to look like a big boobed girl I have some standard silicone forms and also,  a neat trick, some swim forms that use in front of the micro bead forms (less weight that all silicone and the swim form gives heft and shape to the micro bead form. I am 5'6" pretty slim and my figure looks better than before surgery.  I really enjoy the forms.  At home in the evenings though I often just go flat.  My DH doesn't mind all the changes.  I think he enjoys it :)

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2013 02:47PM - edited Mar 30, 2013 03:10PM by beacon800 My first set of silicone foobs were the very smallest ones and they totally sagged too!  I wanted small cause I had been small and didn't want weight considering I have BMX.  I don't use those anymore. You probably need a more structured bra.  I found success with molded cup bras that have some shape built in.  Then the foob fills the space but doesn't create the shape - the bra has the shape.  I don't use mx bras, only off the shelf bras.  I hate tight bras, underwires or anything scratchy.  It can be tricky to find a bra where the cup has enough coverage to hold the foob.  I use many types of foobs and different bras, for different activities.  The most perky (really bombshell) look I can do is with two bras.  I take a very soft, unstructured nylon Hanes Bra (I think it's called Barely There).  It has two layers of fabric in the cup.  I cut one layer open and put the foob in there.  Then, over this bra, I put a structured molded cup bra.  I use the Warners, the one with the little "bump" on the bottom of the cup - I think it's Elements of Bliss.  Since I hate anything tight, i use extenders on both of these.   the first bra holds the foobs near my chest.   The second bra supports the first bra. The look is excellent and it's not uncomfortable.  I have guys checking out my chest all the time when I wear this.  It cracks me up cause it's all fake, but no one, no one, could tell, even in a tight tee shirt.   I use size 4 Natura light Amoena forms for this.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 05:40PM beacon800 wrote: Good to hear the chemo is effective.  My big question:  your onc indicates that if you do one MX, you should do BOTH.  To me that means he thinks you are at a high risk of recurrance/ new primary.  Why else do a prophy MX?  So if you only do lumpectomy, are you reducing your risk of recurrance enough?  If it were me, I would ask for details as to why he thinks a single MX means you should do a double MX, but a lumpectomy would require no prophylactic surgery on the other breast.  Is this just about symmetry or what? I did BMX and made the decision based on numerous risk factors.  These went, roughly in order: the dx of high grade LCIS itself, the fact that my breasts were dense, cystic and proliferative, biopsies of other b9 conditions that raised my risk, my family history spanning two generations, that I had no kids.  All these increased my risk enuf that I wanted to make the surgery.  I was not comfortable waiting for what I felt was too close to call. I think you can review your overall risk factors and make the decision based on multiple factors, not just one.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 02:48PM beacon800 wrote: Shachar, sorry you are in the big bad wating game.  It's scary!!!!  Architectural distortion is just what it sounds like, meaning that the mass is distorting the normal architecture of the breast.  No, your breast is not deformed :) Distraction is a very, very wise idea.  I cannot tell you how many reruns of old sit com TV shows I watched and long, long walks I took and exersize classes I did.  Shopping, that's good too.  In fact, those things help you all the way through, even if you don't get ideal results post biopsy. Scar tissue can cause architectural distortion.  I remember one radiologist doing an ultrasound on me post surgical biopsy and she did an intake of breath and said, "architectural distortion, spiculated" before she could stop herself.  Having been around the block a couple times, I was not at all concerned by her comment.  I expressed the idea that most likely she was in the area of the biopsy incision and seeing the result of that.  And so it was.  Hang in there, get your biopsy and you're going to be ok.  We'll all help.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2013 11:02AM beacon800 wrote: Shayne the surgery can be very different or very similar depending on the cancer type/size/location. One of the biggest differences in AJs case would be that most likely (and I don't know for sure which way she went) she would not have a sentinel node biopsy.  Just this alone makes the recovery vastly easier and faster and the long run side effects profile (cording, lymphedema) much less likely.  If you have invasive cancer, sentinel node biopsy is a necessity.  If you have a cancer nearby the nipple, you cannot do nipple sparing like AJ did.  However, it is somewhat controversial to do nipple sparing on a BRCA+ case.  AJ is taking a small (and I am sure highly calculated) risk on that.  Leaving the nipple does allow a small amount of breast tissue cells to stay on the nipple.  The recurrence data on this is probably very new and constantly changing. I met with the women from FORCE in my area.  They are all BRCA+ and all have bilaterals.  Some were prophy, some were to treat cancer.  None had nipple sparing surgery.  However that was in 2009 and things are always changing.  At that time the highest level of risk reduction included removal of the nipple/aureola complex. There are plenty of women on these boards who had invasive cancer and did do nipple and skin sparing MX, so it is totally possible depending on your unique case.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2011 04:26PM beacon800 wrote: Hope your excision will go well!  I read your path report and though they found a lot, so far it is not alarming.  I understand the fear of finding something worse upon excision.  That is a natural fear - I was worried about that too!  But you can only go with what you have in front of you, not what "might" happen.  The most worrisome are when they find DCIS or LCIS on the core and then go to the excision.  Based on what I read, different studies show a 6-30% chance of finding invasive on excision when the core finds DCIS/LCIS.  Yours is not even that bad, so hopefully nothing worse will be found. BTW, I had schlerosing adenosis, all the usual fibrocystic/coluumnar cell changes, microcalcs, different atypical cells from cyst aspiration, along with PLCIS and LCIS and they never found an invasive or even DCIS.  Nada.  So hope same for you!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2013 07:12PM beacon800 wrote: The radiation will only be for the breast with dcis, not the lcis side.  In general it is advisable to use radiation on lumpectomy treated dcis as the patients have a lower recurrence rate.  This is a long term protection, so a 6 month normal mammo would  not be the most important part. If you do have medical issues that mitigate the use of radiation, you doctor may have other suggestions.  There is a lot of new research in this area and the trend is to less treatment, not more.  So maybe there are some good options if you want to avoid radiation.  It may also depend on the aggressiveness of the cancer cells you have.  There is a poster on these forums:  "Beesie" who is totally expert on DCIS.  Recommend you search for her posts or even PM.  Hope the best for you (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 05:01AM beacon800 wrote: Wow, sorry to hear about the concerning mammo results you have so far. Hopefully this turns out well for you. As for the core biopsy, it's no big deal. I've had quite few of them (sigh) and the lidocaine works well and it won't hurt much. Just stay relaxed and still and it'll be over quick. I much doubt they are doing a sentinel node biopsy along with the core biopsy. If they proposed such a thing to me I would turn it down flat. SNB is a pretty involved procedure requiring a radioactive tracer injected into the breast nearby the known cancerous tumor. They then watch this tracer dye enter the first lymph nodes out of the breast and identify that as the "sentinel" node and remove it (usually several). Anyhow, this is a surgical procedure and is best done along with either lumpectomy or mastectomy, which ever is being done. It is not done in the context of core biopsy. They may see an enlarged node on the films and want to do a fine needle aspiration of that one with your corer biopsy. That is reasonable. Frequently FNA is inconclusive, but maybe this is what they have in mind. Check on this before you undergo the procedure.
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 06:48AM beacon800 wrote: I would turn it down because it is being done at the wrong time. If you do have cancer, you will need lumpectomy or MX and that surgery is the right time to do sentinel node surgery. If your sentinel node is positive, and your tumor is over a certain size, it is normal for them to remove more nodes during the same surgery (called auxiliary node dissection) to appropriately stage the cancer. That is a even more involved procedure. So there is little gained from doing sentinel node surgery at a core biopsy procedure and then turning you around for a second surgery to do the lumpectomy or MX. Another reason is that, if on the lucky chance this thing is not cancer, and they do a sentinel bx which would have been completely unwarranted, you will have the subsequent lifetime risk of lymphedema in that arm and there will have been no reaason for you to have had the nodes out to start with. Sentinel node biopsy is only called for as part of the surgical removal of a biopsy proven cancer, as far as I have ever heard. Who is doing all this to you? Core biopsies are done by radiologists almost all the time. sentinel node biopsies are never done by radiologists, they are done by breast surgeons. So depending on who is seeing you, that will give you an idea.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 08:18PM beacon800 wrote: You are not crazy and don't cancel your MRI.  I am a big believer in following your intuition as long as it does not cause a person to do harmful things. You gave some non specific symptoms but one thing you mentioned was really important: you have exceedingly dense breasts.  That alone is a cancer risk factor, as high as a family hx of cancer in a primary relative.  If your breasts are very dense, mammogram may not be useful.  MRI will be helpful as it works well on dense breasts.  I was increasingly nervous for three years leading up to my diagnosis.  I felt the breast was just going wrong.  I had a family history, dense breasts, fibrocystic breasts.  Ultimately we discovered the problem before it could cause me any major harm.  I feel really glad that I stayed diligent about my mammograms cause that was what found it.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 03:25PM beacon800 wrote: Good for you to have it over with!  BIRADS 0 means "incomplete".  Meaning they cannot say much about what they see.  Maybe some more knowledgable people will chime in on requiring MRI just to get a BIRADS rating.  I have not seen this happen so much. At the moment, you don't have much to worry about as it seems like they don't know either way.  Since it sounds like your breasts are a bit "busy" don't be surprised if they want to biopsy that area.  MRI will see it, for sure, and the washout kinetics (the rate the dye goes in and out of the lesion) will guide their evaluation.  Once the MRI sees something, it's kind of a slam dunk that you get biopsy as it becomes a medical/legal thing.  They are on the hook if they don't biopsy and it turns out they should have. Good luck on the next steps!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 08:10PM beacon800 wrote: Sorry you are facing all this. A bit confused about  your diagnosis.  There is no such thing as invasive DCIS.  The name for dcis is "Ductal Carcinoma In Situ."  The "in situ" means it has not invaded the nearby breast tissue, but is staying inside the lining of the duct. If they find cancer outside of the duct, that would be considered invasive.  Maybe list the details of your path report and people can help you on that.  Your signature says 0/36 nodes removed.  Did you have nodes removed from your arm?  That would be more than expected for a dcis situation.  Is that just on one side or both? As for your recovery, I am 3 years out from bilateral MX.  I am perfectly fine and no problems and it's great!  i do use breast forms, all different types, depending on what I want them for.  Day to day I use the microbead forms from TLC and they are super lightweight (like nothing) and comfortable.  For sports I use foam ones and when I feel like looking quite chesty I use traditional silicone ones.  Overall, my figure is better than before i enjoy being able to switch up the look. It may take 6-8 weeks before you feel even slightly comfortable wearing breast forms and bras.  This is normal.  Just follow how you are feeling and listen to your body.  As times goes by you will be good as new.  Don't try and wear any tight bras and also, when you meet with the fitters for mx bras and forms, be firm about what you  want.  They tried to give me such tight things and I hated them.  I acutally use regular off the shelf bras and add my own sewing to hold a breast form.  I wear a victoria's secret bikini for swimming - those VS people know what they are doing :) Take it slow and easy and you'll be fine.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 11:12PM - edited Jan 9, 2012 11:14PM by beacon800 Hey Farmerlucydaisy, I wanted to talk about the lymphedema risk in a non node prophylactic MX.  As you know, I had BMX and  no sentinel nodes removed.  I was concerned about lymphedema and prior to surgery met with a variety of docs on this subject.  One, Dr. Stanley Rockson, is a well known lymphedema expert. He told me that they very, very rarely see lymphedema after MX where there are no auxillary nodes removed.  Lymphema risk rises if any nodes are removed, but more risk is conferred if more than 5 nodes are removed.  There are nodes inside the breast itself, which will be removed no matter what.  Apparently these do not much increase risk of lymphedema.  However, there are women on this board who had lymphedema even with no sentinel nodes out so the risk is not zero. I asked my radiologist and she said in 15 years she had not seen a woman have lymphedema with MX where they did no sentinel node BX.  I also asked my own surgeon what his clinical experience is and he told me he "just doesn't see" lymphedema after MX where he didn't take aux nodes or sentinel nodes.  So I went and did it, no nodes.  Two years later, so far so good.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 10:32PM beacon800 wrote: Benny, your path report is confusing, but I wanted to try and make some guesses.  From what I understand this is a path report following a core biopsy, correct? If so, the core samples have found DCIS.  DCIS is not an invasive type of cancer, as you know.  However since there is cancer in the nodes, it is clear there is an invasive component, which in all likelihood did not get taken up by the core needle. It is not unusual to find a bunch of different things in a breast and tumors can be mixed, containing DCIS plus other abnormal things, including invasive cancers. In this case the word "metastasized" means it has metastasized to the lymph nodes, but not necessarily to the body as a whole.  It is a fearful thing to see that word, but in your case they really do not know if you have systemic mets.  This is why they will do the CT, PET, etc, so they can get a full picture of what is going on.  Some doctors use that word to describe a cancer that has gone into the lymph nodes from it's orignal source.  I think it sounds really scary and wish they did not say it that way.  Finding "mets to the nodes" is not the same thing as mets to the body.  Many women have postive nodes and survive completely.  If positive nodes are found it is the correct protocol to do the various scans that your doctors are recommending, so they are doing the right thing and it does not mean they think they will definitely find anything.  It's just the next step that is correct to take to give you the  best treatment plan. I know you are so scared and it's been the worst time.  Don't be afraid to seek some counseling or ask for some medication to reduce your anxiety.  Just take things day to day or hour by hour if necessary.  We have all been there, right in your shoes, where sometimes it's all about just getting from one moment to the next.  ALSO don't rely on the stats you see on the net because they are old, outdated and not useful.  Treaments have changed and continue to change so fast that the survival stats are not up to date on the net.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 11:05PM beacon800 wrote: Benny, don't be too sure.  Right now things look terrible and scary and it is easy to assume the worst.  Many, many times women on these boards have felt that various symptoms they had were sure to be signs of systemic spread.  Often times these turned out to be totally non related - arthritis, tendonitis, gallbladder problems, dental problems, lots of things that were NOT cancer.  One thing you can google is tinnitis.  It is so common that almost everyone has it from time to time and many many people have it all the time and most often it does not mean anything more than that.  Take it easy as you can.  If you have a family member or friend that helps you to stay calm or makes you feel safe, keep that person near you now.  One hour at a time, ok?  (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 12:57PM beacon800 wrote: Good luck with your surgery. Sounds like you have all the questions answered. LAstar, I actually went thru quite a bit to avoid the sentinel node surgery on my MX. We did an exhaustive workup, including MRI, core needle biopsy, bilateral excisional biopsies. By the time we went for the mastectomy surgery we had high confidence that no invasive would be found. My onc and I worked up a plan on what we'd do if it was found. All this was a bit more than most people would get, but my insurance went along with it luckily. We did the MX, no invasive found, no sentinel node taken and my recovery was as complete as it could be. When I go see my BS at Stanford, he usually has a student or 2 with him and he says in one short sentence what we did. I usually take them aside and fully explain how great this was and what it saved me, as those students cannot grasp it right away. It's a bit of a gamble, but since sentinel node does not extend survival in any case, only stages it the risk is not crazy considering the workup beforehand. I'd do it again just like that without reservation.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2012 02:18PM beacon800 wrote: This is a controversial subject, that I know.  I do take precautions, meaning I do not over use my arms with heavy lifting, I don't allow arm blood pressure cuffs and when I do have a blood draw from the arm I use a very strict procedure: catheter must be child size, tourniquet is placed over my clothes, tied loosely as possible and removed at the earliest moment.  I bring my own neosporin and band aids to apply after.  I do pay attention to what Dr. Rockson is saying though because he really is one of the foremost lymphedema researchers out there.  I think genetics plays a role.  My mom had 18 nodes out and no LE.  Her aunt (my great aunt) had a big MX in the 1960's when they took everything they could and she never got LE.  In fact, she played golf til she was elderly and died at 83.  She was a long term survivor! I told Rockson my family history and he said they don't have data to prove genetics, but the history was certainly more positive than negative for me regarding LE. In the end we all have to take our own paths.  It does seem there is not enough research for us to be 100% sure of anything.  However, it also seems that LE with the profile I posted is considered rare.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2011 11:33AM beacon800 wrote: Kite I am sorry for your dx.  I do have a question:  how do they know it is a stage 3 cancer at this time.  It sounds like you had a core biopsy, not a complete lumpectomy so I am assuming they did not remove your sentinel lymph node during that process.  What could be the case is that the sample they removed is a grade 3 cancer.  This is not the same as stage 3 cancer.  Grade three means it looks quite significantly abnormal, on a scale of 1-3.  My LCIS was grade 3 in places but stage 0.  So carefully read your path report before you are sure you have stage 3.   ((((hugs to you)))))

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 12:01AM beacon800 wrote: It is scary how easily doctors ask us to have CT scans without thinking much about our long term situations.  However it sounds like in your case it was medically justified so you did what you had to do. I recently declined a CT scan recommended by a pulmonologist.  The symptoms I had then are now gone and I am pretty glad I declined that cat scan.  Unless they really suspect something dire in your lungs I would avoid future scans as much as possible.  I have not heard CT being directly implicated in breast cancer, but overall the risk of some sort of cancer rises as more radiation exposure occurs.  I would go ahead and practice healthy lifestyle activities, such as correct weight, good excersize, supplement vit D, healfutl diet, limit alchohol, no smoking and also do your monthly breast self exams.  Right now these are the best you can do to prevent any cancers, including breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 01:59PM beacon800 wrote: I have been in your shoes, waiting for a stereotactic bx. I was scared of the procedure, scared that I even needed the procedure and very concerned about the results. Bad time! Here is the deal: the procedure is ok. Tough part is lying in a fixed position for a while as they do the work. Here's some advice - wear a front closing bra and a button up shirt. These are much easier to put on afterwards. Bring some warm fluffy socks and wear these instead of your shoes for lying on the table. If you have long hair, put it in a scrunchy so it won't annoy you while lying there. If you feel panic, ask for a Valium. It's not unusual for them to give these for the test. Have some extra ice packs at home, you want these for the whole day, off and on. Stock your hou with stuff you like, chocolate, ice cream, whatever makes you happy, as a reward for getting thru. Honest it's not as bad as all that. Mine did not hurt at all. Hang in there and I wish you B9 result!

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 12:13PM beacon800 wrote: Hi Babsplus5 - sorry to hear you have LCIS but happy that it is not worse.  Considering you had excision, I would be fairly confident in the results (as opposed to core only).  Get your path report and find out if they acheived clear margins on the LCIS.  If they did, then you can be quite confident.  Even if they did not, and this is typical with LCIS not to get clear margins, it is still something you should know and I would still feel reasonably good about your chances of having found what there was to find. I get it about MRI opening a can of worms.  It often does.  However it will give you the best view of everything going on in your breast.  Often the protocol for LCIS is tamoxifen plus high surveillance.  This surveillance often includes a mammogram followed by six month interval to MRI, rinse, repeat.  If your breasts are quite dense, MRI really is important to find early cancer. I did take all my slides to a major cancer center and happily they agreed with the first reading.

It went fine and it did not hurt.  If you have some meds you can take prior that is your best bet and also use the bathroom right beforehand.  Don't drink a ton of liquids prior.   I wore my most comfy sweats and put on some big fluffy socks before I went up on the table.  They will give you blankets and do the best to make you comfortable.  I put my hair in a ponytail holder so it would not flop around and irriate me or itch or anything that would make me want to move.  It's ok, seriously, thinking about it before hand was much worse than the actual.  You can do it!!

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 02:04PM beacon800 wrote: Based on what little I know, your family history, while significant, is not extremely indicative of a BRCA mutation.  I did genetic counseling at Stanford and ran the BRCA, negative result.  However my mom had bc, so did her two aunts above her.  Her dad had prostate cancer.  Based on this, the oncologist said my risk of BRCA positive was quite low, but we would test to be sure.  She was right, negative result. What I am saying is that even a family history does not guarantee a BRCA positive, so don't worry too much til you get your results.  Check the website for FORCE, (facing our risk empowered) which gives a lot of info on genetic risks.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 08:17PM beacon800 wrote: Momo - your story is slightly similar to my own, in terms of "you've got cancer - ooops no you don't".  My needle biopsy was done for new micro calcs.  As it turned out, I had a nearby appt w/ my gyn and she had my biospy results.  She told me, " it's positive, you've got breast cancer, I am sorry."  Hit me like a ton of bricks.  She did the exam and I was so numb, but at the end I asked for the path report, got off the table and walked to the office of a breast surgeon I know.  She told me, "oh no, that's not breast cancer, that's LCIS, no cancer."  Well crap!  My head was spinning.  Anyhow I get where you are coming from, it's very disorienting. I suggest you try and stay as calm and detached until they do the lumpectomy and see what that brings.  If they don't find anything more, then you need to CELEBRATE!  Yes, it's a first class pain to be "high risk" and you may have BMX down the line but you are ok and you will be on top of this thing and you will not let it get past a point.  I know it is upsetting and I totally personally undestand why you want the BMX, just for peace of mind.  But hang in there. Your emotions will move around and you will feel different from time to time.  Trust me on this -  you will not be super scared indefinitely.
Posts.Title: microcalcifications and now... panic! momoschki vmudrow

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 01:41AM beacon800 wrote: Wow, how strange. I have not had this happen, but have too much experience in this area, so here are some thoughts: When you first walked in the treatment room, the images on the computer were from your mammogram. There is a slim chance they were not your films. I always made sure both my name and date of birth were correct on the screens. I was surprised when I saw how many names there were so close to my own. (I know one should never see these, but sometimes you do). So have someone check it closely. The posture on the table is obviously much different from posture for the mammo, so potentially if you have very dense breasts the calcs could have shifted under some tissue and been hard to see. Other thing, a very long shot, is that you have milk of calcium, a b9 condition and the calcs moved around from the posture shift on the table. This seems unlikely as it should be easy to tell you had milk of calcium and therefore you would not need biopsy. So, let us know what your doc says - it's weird that this happened!

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 08:30PM beacon800 wrote: For you ladies who are suffering, questioning your attractiveness and suffering from the loss, I really want to hug each one of you.  I have studied recon a bit (I elected not to reconstruct) and realized that even recon does not necessarily confer confidence and self worth.  We have lost something and that is the fact. Five days after my bilateral, when I was a weak, exhausted and weepy thing, reacting badly to some drugs I was taking and still had the drains in, I took my husband's hand and put it on my scar.  I looked at him and told him, "I want you to touch me here and see if you can still accept me." To this moment I can vividly see the slight smile on his face as it softened, "oh darling", he whispered, he almost laughed, just a little. In that moment I was born again.  I could see he did not mind, that he was ok with me and I decided right then that I was ok with me too. I wish for each of you to find your self acceptance and overcome the loss.   (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2011 11:56AM beacon800 wrote: Kite I want to say something about your change in meds.  I totally understand why they took you off the RA medicine.  That type of med is usually a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor and would not be smart to take while you have breast cancer.  Right before I got my breast problems, I developed severe hives and angioedema.  In order to do my surgeries safely I had to have iv prednisone and take it for five days thereafter.  I hated it, but it controlled my hives and angioedema.  (if you want to scare an anesthesiology dept just tell them you have idiopathic angioedema, but I digress).  Anyhow, my immunologist told me then to take the prednisone for no more than five days as longer term use could push stray cancer cells to my peripheral lymphatic system.  I don't know why this would happen but this is what she told me.  So in your case, you might talk it over with an oncologist and try to take the least prednisone and use other things if at all possible.  I know this is a nightmare, but it can all get better.  Mine did, all gone.  And no kidding, for a couple times I did kinda want to die.  But it's all fine now and my life is TOTALLY normal.  Wishing the same for you.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 01:30AM beacon800 wrote: Yes Benny, you will be able to tack up your horse. But at first, you will have someone help you with the saddle. You can do the bridle. Don't throw around the 50pd bales of hay for a good long time. Take the hay in leaves to your horse instead. Same with heavy things like water buckets. Right now you should not do those things. However, I now do all those things and it's ok. Just take it slow and understand that you will be in a learning mode about how fast your body is healing, what it can handle and so on. Over time you may find you are able to do everything you ever did before. Frankly, I think most women do find that their activities are not significantly limited by breast surgery. As for anesthesia - the people working on you do this every day. Their patients live through it and so will you. It's scary to you cause you never did it. For them it is totally routine. Like for you riding a horse is easy and for them, they might be scared. It's all about what you are used to. So just relax and for sure you will find that it's over quickly and less miserable then you thought. Almost none of us thout we could do it and we did and so will you. (((hugs)))
